#Text=CHAPTER XXI .
#Text=BILLY TAKES HER TURN AT QUESTIONING
#Text=Arkwright did not call to see Alice Greggory for some days .
#Text=He did not want to see Alice now .

#Text=He told himself wearily that she could not help him fight this tiger skin that lay across his path , The very fact of her presence by his side would , indeed , incapacitate himself for fighting .
#Text=So he deliberately stayed away from the Annex until the day before he sailed for Germany .
#Text=Then he went out to say good-by .

#Text=Chagrined as he was at what he termed his imbecile stupidity in not knowing his own heart all these past months , and convinced , as he also was , that Alice and Calderwell cared for each other , he could see no way for him but to play the part of a man of kindliness and honor , leaving a clear field for his preferred rival , and bringing no shadow of regret to mar the happiness of the girl he loved .

#Text=As for being his old easy , frank self on this last call , however , that was impossible ; so Alice found plenty of fuel for her still burning fires of suspicion -- fires which had , indeed , blazed up anew at this second long period of absence on the part of Arkwright .
#Text=Naturally , therefore , the call was anything but a joy and comfort to either one .
#Text=Arkwright was nervous , gloomy , and abnormally gay by turns .
#Text=Alice was nervous and abnormally gay all the time .
#Text=Then they said good-by and Arkwright went away .
#Text=He sailed the next day , and Alice settled down to the summer of study and hard work she had laid out for herself .
#Text=On the tenth of September Billy came home .
#Text=She was brown , plump-cheeked , and smiling .
#Text=She declared that she had had a perfectly beautiful time , and that there could n't be anything in the world nicer than the trip she and Bertram had taken -- just they two together .
#Text=In answer to Aunt Hannah 's solicitous inquiries , she asserted that she was all well and rested now .
#Text=But there was a vaguely troubled questioning in her eyes that Aunt Hannah did not quite like .
#Text=Aunt Hannah , however , said nothing even to Billy herself about this .
#Text=One of the first friends
#Text=Billy saw after her return was Hugh Calderwell .
#Text=As it happened Bertram was out when he came , so Billy had the first half-hour of the call to herself .
#Text=She was not sorry for this , as it gave her a chance to question Calderwell a little concerning Alice Greggory -- something she had long ago determined to do at the first opportunity .
#Text=“ Now tell me everything -- everything about everybody , ” she began diplomatically , settling herself comfortably for a good visit .
#Text=“ Thank you ,

#Text=I 'm well , and have had a passably agreeable summer , barring the heat , sundry persistent mosquitoes , several grievous disappointments , and a felon on my thumb , ” he began , with shameless imperturbability .
#Text=“ I have been to Revere once , to the circus once , to Nantasket three times , and to Keith 's and the ' movies ' ten times , perhaps -- to be accurate .
#Text=I have also --
#Text=But perhaps there was some one else you desired to inquire for , ” he broke off , turning upon his hostess a bland but unsmiling countenance .
#Text=“ Oh , no , how could there be ? ” twinkled Billy .
#Text=“ Really , Hugh , I always knew you had a pretty good opinion of yourself , but I did n't credit you with thinking you were everybody .
#Text=Go on .
#Text=I 'm so interested ! ”
#Text=Hugh chuckled softly ; but there was a plaintive tone in his voice as he answered .
#Text=“ Thanks , no .
#Text=I 've rather lost my interest now .
#Text=Lack of appreciation always did discourage me .
#Text=We 'll talk of something else , please .
#Text=You enjoyed your trip ? ”
#Text=“ Very much .
#Text=It just could n't have been nicer ! ”
#Text=“ You were lucky .
#Text=The heat here has been something fierce ! ”
#Text=“ What made you stay ? ”
#Text=“ Reasons too numerous , and one too heart-breaking , to mention .
#Text=Besides , you forget , ” with dignity .
#Text=“ There is my profession .
#Text=I have joined the workers of the world now , you know . ”
#Text=“ Oh , fudge , Hugh ! ” laughed Billy .
#Text=“ You know very well you 're as likely as not to start for the ends of the earth to-morrow morning ! ”
#Text=Hugh drew himself up .
#Text=“ I do n't seem to succeed in making people understand that I 'm serious , ” he began aggrievedly .
#Text=“ I -- ” With an expressive flourish of his hands he relaxed suddenly , and fell back in his chair .
#Text=A slow smile came to his lips .
#Text=“ Well , Billy , I 'll give up .
#Text=You 've hit it , ” he confessed .
#Text=“ I have thought seriously of starting to-morrow morning for half-way to the ends of the earth -- Panama . ”
#Text=“ Hugh ! ”
#Text=“ Well , I have .
#Text=Even this call was to be a good-by -- if I went . ”
#Text=“ Oh , Hugh ! But I really thought -- in spite of my teasing -- that you had settled down , this time . ”
#Text=“ Yes , so did I , ” sighed the man , a little soberly .
#Text=“ But I guess it 's no use , Billy .
#Text=Oh , I 'm coming back , of course , and link arms again with their worthy Highnesses , John Doe and Richard Roe ; but just now I 've got a restless fit on me .
#Text=I want to see the wheels go ' round .
#Text=Of course , if I had my bread and butter and cigars to earn , ' twould be different .
#Text=But I have n't , and I know I have n't ; and I suspect that 's where the trouble lies .
#Text=If it was n't for those natal silver spoons of mine that Bertram is always talking about , things might be different .

#Text=But the spoons are there , and always have been ; and I know they 're all ready to dish out mountains to climb and lakes to paddle in , any time I 've a mind to say the word . So -- I just say the word .
#Text=That 's all . ”
